en_second_half: was something gorgeous about him, some heightened sensitivity to the promises of life, as if he were related to one of those intricate machines that register earthquakes ten thousand miles away. Mi amigo, que se llamaba Henry, me recibió en la puerta con una sonrisa cálida y me llevó a la terraza, donde su esposa, Elizabeth, nos esperaba con refrescos y canapés. La conversación fue fácil y agradable, y pronto me encontré sumergido en historias de su infancia y sus aventuras en el extranjero. Mientras hablábamos, no pude evitar notar la forma en que la luz del sol se reflejaba en el agua de la bahía, creando un efecto hipnótico que parecía suspender el tiempo. La tarde se deslizó sin que me diera cuenta, y antes de que me fuera posible darme cuenta, el sol comenzaba a ponerse, tiñendo el cielo de tonos rosados y anaranjados. Fue entonces cuando Henry me invitó a unirme a ellos para una cena al aire libre en la playa, y no pude resistir la oportunidad de prolongar aquella velada mágica. Así que, con la luz de las estrellas comenzando a aparecer en el cielo, nos sentamos alrededor de una mesa blanca, rodeados de velas y de la suave brisa marina, y nos dispusimos a disfrutar de una noche que prometía ser inolvidable.

en_second_half: white cake of apartment-houses. Throwing a regal homecoming glance around the neighbourhood, Mrs. Wilson gathered up her dog and her other purchases, and went haughtily in.

en_results_raw: of traffic that stretched out before us like a frozen river. The driver, a gruff but kind-eyed man with a thick accent, turned around and said, "You folks okay? This traffic's gonna be here for a while." My companion, a petite woman with a sharp jawline and piercing green eyes, leaned forward and asked, "How long do you think it'll take to get to the West Hundreds?" The driver shrugged, "Could be an hour, could be two. Depends on how the traffic breaks." We sat in silence for a moment, watching as the minutes ticked by on the dashboard clock. The woman finally spoke up, "I'm Rachel, by the way." I turned to her and smiled, "I'm Alex. Nice to meet you, Rachel." We chatted idly for a bit, exchanging small talk about the city and our lives, as the cab inched forward at a glacial pace. As we approached the West Hundreds, the towering skyscrapers gave way to smaller, more rundown buildings, and the sounds of the city changed from the hum of traffic to the wail of sirens and the shouts of pedestrians. The driver finally turned onto our street, and we pulled up in front of a nondescript office building. Rachel gathered her things and turned to me, "Well, this is my stop. It was nice meeting you, Alex." I smiled and nodded, "Likewise, Rachel. Maybe I'll see you around." She smiled back and stepped out of the cab, disappearing into the crowded sidewalk. The driver turned to me and said, "Where to now, buddy?" I thought for a moment before responding, "Just take me to the nearest subway station, please."

en_results_raw: get a hearing, and then I had to speak in a loud, clear voice to be audible to the farthest of them. I told them that I had come from a world beyond their world, a world where such things as they had witnessed were the commonplaces of life. I told them of the mighty engines that roared through the skies, of the huge buildings that towered above the trees, of the strange, two-wheeled vehicles that sped along the roads without the aid of horses. I told them of the people, too, of their strange customs and their stranger garb. And as I spoke, I could see the wonder growing in their eyes, the awe and the amazement. They had never heard of such things before, and they could hardly credit them. But I could see, too, a glimmer of fear, a fear that I was some kind of magician, some kind of sorcerer who had come to bewilder and deceive them. And so I told them of my peaceful intentions, of my desire to learn from them and to teach them in return. I told them that I meant no harm, that I was a friend. And slowly, gradually, they began to believe me.
